channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Stimulus Spending Drove Poverty Lower Again in 2021, Census Bureau Reports
item.description: A measure that accounts for all federal subsidies showed that fewer people experienced severe economic hardship, while health insurance coverage rose.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Jason DeParle
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers gave groceries to families experiencing food insecurity outside a food pantry in Houston in August.

item.title: Markets Shudder on Higher-Than-Expected Inflation Numbers
item.description: Stocks plunged and government bond yields jumped higher as investors were wrong-footed by data showing stubbornly high price increases last month.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: The Critical Moment Behind Ukraine’s Rapid Advance
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky wanted to make a dramatic move in the war against Russia. U.S. and Ukrainian officials came up with a plan.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near the Kherson front this month.

item.title: Clashes Erupt Between Armenia and Azerbaijan in Nagorno-Karabakh
item.description: The simmering conflict over the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region last flared in 2020, when Russia brokered a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Armenian soldiers and a Russian peacekeeping soldier, on the vehicle, at a checkpoint in Nagorno-Karabakh in 2020.

item.title: Xi’s China and Biden’s U.S.: It Feels Like a Cold War
item.description: Even at their worst moments, the Americans and the Soviets kept talking. Today, U.S.-China contacts are scarce, while Beijing and Moscow move closer together.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden during a virtual meeting in November with Xi Jinping, China’s leader. They have spoken only five times since early 2021.

item.title: Challenges for Russia and China Test a ‘No-Limits’ Friendship
item.description: Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping are set to meet later this week. Russia’s battlefield losses and China’s slowdown could complicate their relationship.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher, Anton Troianovski and Jane Perlez
item.media:credit: Alexei Druzhinin/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, in Beijing in February. The two are expected to meet again this week in Uzbekistan.

item.title: King Charles Inherits Riches, and Passes Off His Own Empire
item.description: As prince, Charles used tax breaks, offshore accounts and canny real estate investments to turn a sleepy estate into a billion-dollar business.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley and Euan Ward
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III spent years turning his royal estate into a billion-dollar portfolio.

item.title: Charles Visits Northern Ireland Before Queen’s Coffin Arrives in London
item.description: The new monarch continued his tour of the nations of the United Kingdom and will travel back to the capital later as his mother’s coffin is taken to Buckingham Palace.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Niall Carson
item.media:description: King Charles III, accompanied by Camilla, the queen consort, spoke at Hillsborough Castle in Northern Ireland on Tuesday. “My mother saw Northern Ireland pass through momentous and historic changes,” he said.

item.title: Unearthing a Maya Civilization That ‘Punched Above its Weight’
item.description: Before the pandemic, the long-sought ruins of Sak Tz’i’, a small but influential Mesoamerican kingdom, were discovered on a cattle ranch in Mexico. This summer archaeologists returned to excavate it.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz and Meghan Dhaliwal
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: A stone panel, dating to the eighth century A.D., of K’ab Kante’, a ruler of the ancient Maya kingdom of Sak Tz’i’. The ruins of Lakanjá Tzeltal, a settlement at least 2,500 years old, were discovered in Chiapas, Mexico.

item.title: Justice Dept. Issues 40 Subpoenas in a Week, Expanding Its Jan. 6 Inquiry
item.description: It also seized the phones of two top Trump advisers, a sign of an escalating investigation two months before the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Maggie Haberman, Adam Goldman and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: The mob at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The Justice Department has spent more than a year focused on investigating rioters at the Capitol but has more recently been issuing subpoenas to figures closer to former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Archives Is Unsure Whether Trump Surrendered All Records, Panel Says
item.description: In a letter, the chairwoman of the House Oversight and Reform Committee said the National Archives told her staff it was still not certain whether all presidential records had been returned.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Carolyn B. Maloney requested a formal assessment from the National Archives of what presidential records, if any, removed from the White House by former President Donald J. Trump remained unaccounted for.

item.title: Is Ron DeSantis the Future of the Republican Party?
item.description: For years, Democrats have worried about the prospect of a more disciplined heir to Trump. In Florida’s pugilistic governor, that candidate may have arrived.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Jamie Chung for The New York Times

item.title: Why Things May Really Be Different for This Midterm Election
item.description: This cycle, the arguments for Democratic strength cut against the conventional wisdom that the party in power struggles in midterms.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn

item.title: Jean-Luc Godard, Daring Director Who Shaped the French New Wave, Dies at 91
item.description: The Franco-Swiss filmmaker and provocateur radically rethought motion pictures and left a lasting influence on the medium.
item.dc:creator: Dave Kehr and Jonathan Kandell
item.media:credit: Sam Falk/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jean-Luc Godard in 1964.

item.title: The Best and Worst Moments of the 2022 Emmys
item.description: The show returned to a pre-Covid format, with the usual array of leaden gags, shameless commercialism and genuinely poignant moments.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Emmy host, Kenan Thompson, bottom center, opened the show with a number based on TV theme songs.

item.title: ‘Succession’ Wins Best Drama at Emmys as HBO Triumphs Again
item.description: It was the sixth time in eight years that HBO has taken the television industry’s biggest prize for a recurring series. “Ted Lasso” won best comedy.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Jesse Armstrong, the creator of “Succession,” with the cast accepting the Emmy for best drama on Monday night.

item.title: The Cartoonist Kate Beaton Found Humor, and Humanity, in Canada’s Oil Fields
item.description: Kate Beaton headed to the tar sand fields of Alberta saddled with loans and in need of cash. She found a job — and the book she “was always going to make.”
item.dc:creator: Robert Ito
item.category: Ducks: Two Years in the Oil Sands (Book)
item.media:credit: Paul Atwood for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kate Beaton in her home office, in Mabou, Cape Breton, in Nova Scotia.

item.title: Sally Schmitt’s French Laundry
item.description: Sally Schmitt sold the French Laundry. Then it became “the best restaurant in the world.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Proudfoot

item.title: It Is a Well-Known Truth That Opponents of Democracy Don’t Want You to Have Nice Things
item.description: What makes a democracy robust?
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Boston Globe / Getty Images
item.media:description: Striking bus drivers in Boston in 1987.

item.title: We’ve Waited Our Whole Lives to Help Our Father, David Milch, Tell This Story
item.description: We’d always been listening.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Milch and Olivia Milch
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; image by Hans Neleman via Getty Images

item.title: ‘Quiet Quitting’ Is Not the Solution to Burnout
item.description: As counterintuitive as it seems, adding new, energizing activities to your schedule just might make life feel more doable.
item.dc:creator: Laura Vanderkam
item.media:credit: Karl Fletcher/500px, via Getty Images

item.title: Friedrich Schelling’s Philosophy Can Help Us Through the Climate Crisis
item.description: Friedrich Schelling’s ideas might provide a foundation on which to anchor the fight for our climate and our survival.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Wulf
item.media:credit: Evan Cohen

item.title: Ukraine Deflates MAGA Macho Myths
item.description: Sometimes tough guys finish last. Can the right handle it?
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman

item.title: We Build Civilizations on Status. But We Barely Understand It.
item.description: The sociologist Cecilia Ridgeway explains how status shapes our world — and our lives.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
item.category: Status: Why Is It Everywhere? Why Does It Matter? (Book)
item.media:credit: Courtesy of Cecilia Ridgeway

item.title: Ukraine on the March
item.description: It’s not just one region. Ukraine is making progress in multiple places.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kostiantyn Liberov/Associated Press
item.media:description: A Ukrainian tank in the Kharkiv region yesterday.

item.title: Is Ukraine Turning the Tide in the War?
item.description: What the country’s biggest victory since the beginning of the war means for the future of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Sydney Harper, Mooj Zadie, M.J. Davis Lin, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Juan Barreto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on an abandoned Russian tank last week. The Ukrainians have launched a stunning counteroffensive against Russia.

item.title: Jennifer Egan and the Goon Squad
item.description: The novelist talks about her Pulitzer-winning book, which includes one chapter written as a PowerPoint presentation, and Stephen Fry discusses Greek mythology.

item.title: Breakfast With Grandma
item.description: A new New Yorker tucks into the West Village’s offerings with her Abueti, a longtime Manhattanite.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Sichynsky
item.media:credit: Moriah Sawtelle
item.media:description: If you need a more portable breakfast, St. Jardim’s egg sandwich with smoked bacon, tomato jam and greens always satisfies.

item.title: Chuck Schumer to Push $15 Million Into Democrats’ Fight to Hold Senate
item.description: Chuck Schumer, the Senate majority leader, is said to be planning to transfer part of his war chest to key Democratic candidates as well as to the party’s Senate campaign arm.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the majority leader, had nearly $38 million in cash on hand for his re-election bid as of his last campaign finance report, at the end of June.

item.title: New York Lawmakers Call for More Oversight of Hasidic Schools
item.description: After a New York Times investigation found that many of the private religious schools denied students a basic education, top officials voiced serious concerns.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro, Brian M. Rosenthal and Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York Times investigation found that many Hasidic schools appear to be operating in violation of state law by denying thousands of students a basic education.

item.title: What Is Brain Fog and How Can I Treat It?
item.description: Researchers are just beginning to understand the cognitive dysfunction that some people experience with Covid-19 and a range of other health issues.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Is Barefoot Weight Lifting Safe?
item.description: This strength training practice can fortify your feet, but experts warn that it’s not without risk.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Just 2 Minutes of Walking After a Meal Is Surprisingly Good for You
item.description: A new paper suggests that it takes far less exercise than was previously thought to lower blood sugar after eating.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: krblokhin/Getty Images
item.media:description: A short walk can have a significant impact on blood sugar levels.

item.title: The Joy Workout
item.description: Six research-backed moves to improve your mood
item.dc:creator: Kelly McGonigal
item.media:credit: na

item.title: How Runners Can Stay Visible as the Daylight Hours Shrink
item.description: Wearing lights and reflective gear can help drivers see you when running in the dark.
item.dc:creator: Jen A. Miller
item.media:credit: iStock by Getty Images

item.title: At 75, the Father of Environmental Justice Meets the Moment
item.description: The White House has pledged $60 billion to a cause Robert Bullard has championed since the late seventies. He wants guarantees that the money will end up in the right hands.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.category: White House Council on Environmental Quality
item.media:credit: Michael Starghill Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert Bullard doesn’t recall when people started calling him the father of environmental justice. “It’s really a compliment,” he said. “I’ve been called worse.”
